Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Plant Genomics and Biotechnology
Award.AbstractNarration: A Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Sites award has been made to Washington State University that will provide research training for 8 students, for 10 weeks during the summers of 2012- 2014. The program focuses on genomics and biotechnology -- the application of gene-guided knowledge in addressing issues in plant and animal biology. Student projects will be based on integrating the principles of genomics and biotechnology with other disciplines such as plant biotechnology, genetics and breeding, plant physiology, calcium signaling, computational biology, food science, plant pathology, and bioinformatics. Faculty members from Departments of Horticulture, Molecular Plant Sciences, Computer Science, Plant Pathology, Crops and Soils Science and Food Science will serve as mentors. There is a wide range of engaging and exciting projects for students. Students are expected to do full-time lab research as well as participate in seminars and various workshops, such as scientific writing, ethics in science and the responsible conduct in research, professional career development and critical thinking. Students are also provided educational visits of the local agricultural industries ranging from wheat to fruit production and processing. REU students have access to a large array of individual mentor's facilities as well as several interdepartmental labs and centers with core facilities such as genomics with the latest sequencing technologies, microarray printing and analysis, electron microscopy etc. The research experience will conclude with a seminar presentation and a campus-wide undergraduate poster presentation event. The program's multi-pronged recruitment efforts comprise of traditional 'hard copy" formats and digital media advertising. Students are selected based on academic record, prior research experience and potential for outstanding research in genetics, genomics, molecular biology and biotechnology. Students are tracked by establishing an online community of undergraduate researchers to determine their continued interest in their academic field of study, their career paths, and the lasting influences of the research experience. Information about the program will be assessed by various means, including use of an REU common assessment tool. More information is available by visiting http://genomics.wsu.edu/pages/team/undergraduate/index.html, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Amit Dhingra, adhingra@wsu.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
A well-prepared, innovative science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) workforce is crucial to the nation's health and economy. The NSF REU project on Plant Genomics and Biotechnology at Washington State University focused on preparing undergraduate students to meet the food, feed, fiber and fuel challenges that our planet faces as the population inches towards 10 billion by 2050.  From 2012-2015, a total of 25 undergraduate students participated in this REU program from the follwoing 11 states: New Jersey, Connecticut, Maryland, Georgia, Florida, North Carolina, South Carolina, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Washington and Idaho.  

Intellectual merit: During the 10 weeks of the program, each REU student worked directly with the professor and a graduate student mentor. Genomics and biotechnology approaches were applied to the disciplines of plant physiology, plant pathology, plant breeding, genetic diversity and conservation, food biotechnology, and weed biology to address various challenges tied to the sustenance of people worldwide.

A novel study to combat the scourge of cereal rust fungi that represent destructive pathogens affecting grain production globally was investigated by a student and his work was published in a peer reviewed publication.

Who doesn’t love apples? Thanks to the work done by one student, disease resistant apples that do not fall prey to fire blight, a bacterial disease that results in major losses to our farmers, will be on the shelf soon.

Another project focused on identifying ways to increase carbon capture in Camelina to enhance jet fuel production using oil from this plant’s seeds.

Given the recent E. coli outbreaks, food safety is paramount on everyone’s mind. Using a DNA-based approach, a student quantified the bacterial load on fruit coming out of the farms and identified best ways to reduce the microbial load to keep our food safe.

A few student projects focused on understanding the genetic diversity of indigenous plants important to Native American ecosystems with the aim of conserving these critical natural resources.

Did you know that most horticultural crops are harvested manually? Given the labor shortage and short time window in which one must harvest a crop, several groups are working on building mechanical harvesters. However, if the plant product doesn’t release easily from the plant, the harvesters end up damaging the produce. A student investigated a novel genetic mechanism to induce the development of a separation layer in cherry between the fruit and the stem to make mechanical harvesting efficient.

Your eyes might water at the thought of an onion. But it’s not all tears since there are sweet varieties of onions that grow in the Pacific Northwest. Bacteria also love the sugars and farmers need to know if their premium quality sweet onions contain bacteria. A student investigated genomics approaches to quantify the presence of bacteria to ensure that every piece of onion the consumer buys is safe.

Broader impacts:  Direct involvement in the research projects allowed the students to develop their own capabilities in the laboratory-based research. They learned about experimental design, gained new skills with laboratory techniques, and learned how to record, analyze, and interpret data. Presentation of research results at different forums enabled the students to hone their communication skills. In addition, they gained insight into what it takes to work successfully with other researchers and the importance of collaboration in scientific exploration. These projects also created teaching, training and learning opportunities for the graduate students who were involved in the mentoring of undergraduate students.
